facts.text: Jayaram Mudaliar purchased leasehold land for Rs. 10,500 from Munisami Mudaliar and others under sale deed Exhibit B-7 dated 7-7-1958.

anchor.surface_text: Jayaram Mudaliar, the Appellant before us by Special Leave, purchased some lease hold land for Rs. 10,500/- from Munisami Mudaliar and others under a sale deed of 7-7-1958  Exhibit B-7  and some other lands

facts.text: Jayaram Mudaliar purchased lands for Rs. 6,550 at public auction under sales certificate Exhibit B-51 dated 15-7-1960 to realise dues for loans taken by Munisami Mudaliar under Land Improvement Loans Act.

anchor.surface_text: and some other lands shown in a sales certificate dated 15-7-1960,  Exhibit B-51  sold to him for Rs. 6,550/- at a public auction of immovable property held to realise the dues in respect of loans taken by Munisami Mudaliar under the Land Improvement Loans Act 19 of 1883.

facts.text: Partition suit commenced by pauper application dated 23-6-1958 filed by plaintiff-respondent Ayyaswami Mudaliar in Vellore, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Both Jayaram and Munisami, mentioned above, were impleaded as defendants in a Partition suit, in Vellore, Madras, now before us in appeal, commenced by a pauper application dated 23-6-1958 filed by the plaintiff-respondent Ayyaswami Mudaliar so that the suit must be deemed to have been, filed on that date.

facts.text: Plaintiff amended plaint on 18-9-1961 challenging validity of sales on ground of lis pendens under section 52 Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff respondent before us had challenged, by an amendment of his plaint on 18-9-1961, the validity of the sales of land mentioned above, consisting of items given in schedule B to the plaint, on the ground, inter-alia, that these sales, of joint property in suit, were struck by the doctrine of lis pendens embodied in section 52 of the Indian Transfer of Property Act.

facts.text: Trial Court and First Appellate Court held lis pendens applied to both sales; High Court substantially dismissed second appeal on 19-7-1968.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court and the Court of first appeal having held that the rule of lis pendens applied to the sales mentioned above, the appellant purchaser had filed a second appeal in the High Court of Madras, which was substantially dismissed by a learned Judge of that Court, on 19-7-1968, after a modification of the decree.

facts.text: Appellant did not apply for Letters Patent appeal certificate immediately after High Court judgment as per Rule 28 Order IV Madras High Court Rules; applied later, rejected on 6-9-1968.

anchor.surface_text: Leave to file a Letters Patent appeal was not asked for in the manner required by Rule 28, Order IV of the Rules of Madras High Court... rejected on 6-9-1968 on the ground that it had not been made at the proper time.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave for Civil Appeal No. 2152 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2152 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 19, 1968 of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 1173 of 1964.

facts.text: Properties in Schedule B are joint family properties; Munisami Mudaliar is karta.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court had found that the properties given in Schedule B were joint family properties of which the defendant respondent Munisami was the karta in possession. This finding was affirmed by the first Appellate Court and was not touched in the High Court.

facts.text: Munisami and Jayaram denied properties were joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant-respondent Munisami and the defendant appellant Jayaram had both pleaded that the properties in suit were acquired by Munisami with his own funds obtained by separate business in partnership with a stranger and that Ayyaswami, plaintiff, had no share in these properties.

facts.text: Sale deed Ex. B7 executed by Munisami Mudaliar and his sons (Subramanian, Jagannathan, Duraisami alias Thanikachalam, Vijayarangam), not including plaintiff Ayyaswami.

anchor.surface_text: the ostensibly voluntary sale of 7-7-1958 under a sale deed by the defendant Munisami Mudaliar and his major son Subramanian Mudaliar and three minor sons Jagannathan, Duraisami alias Thanikachalam, and Vijayarangam in favour of the defendant appellant

facts.text: Revenue sale under Ex. B51 for pumpset arrears under hire purchase due from Munisami Mudaliar.

anchor.surface_text: secondly, there was the sale evidenced by the,. sale certificate  Exhibit B. 51  of 15-7-1960 showing that the auction sale was held in order to realise certain, arrears under hire purchase system due to Shri O. D. Munisami Mudaliar.

facts.text: Trial Court found sales Ex. B7 and B51 true, supported by consideration, but affected by lis pendens.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court recorded a finding... There is overwhelming documentary and oral evidence to show that the sale deed Exhibit B.7 and the revenue sale are all true and supported by consideration and that the 12th Defendant would be entitled to them, if these sales were not affected by the rule of lis pendens

facts.text: High Court held voluntary sale Ex. B7 hit by lis pendens; for revenue sale Ex. B51, only properties improved by loans excluded.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madras had described the sale of 7-7-1958 as a voluntary alienation, and, thereby, placed it on a footing different from an involuntary sale... Regarding Ex. B51 the High Court... held that only that land sold was to be excluded from the purview of the principle of lis pendens for the improvement of which some loan was taken.

facts.text: Munisami executed mortgage on 17-1-1944 for Rs. 7,500 in favour of Kannayiram on some Schedule B properties.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that, on 17-1-1944, Munisami had executed a mortgage of some of the property in Schedule B of the plaint for Rs. 7,500/ in favour of Kannayiram

facts.text: Jayaram obtained preliminary decree on 25-1-1956 and final decree on 14-9-1957 in suit No. 2/1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had obtained a preliminary decree on 25-1-1956 in his suit and a final decree on 14-9-1957.

facts.text: Plaintiff Ayyaswami is member of joint family with Munisami as karta.

anchor.surface_text: the joint family of which plaintiff-respondent Ayyaswami was a member.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, upheld lis pendens application with modifications for revenue sale.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, there is no force in this appeal which is dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Proviso to s.7(1)(c) Land Improvement Loans Act: proceedings do not affect prior interests other than borrower's.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that no proceeding in respect of any land under clause (c) shall affect any interest in that land which existed before the date of the order granting the loan, other than the interest of the borrower

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the borrower had himself taken up the case that the loan was taken by him individually, for the purpose of purchasing a pumping-set installed. on the land.

facts.text: High Court Rule 28 Order IV requires oral application for Letters Patent certificate immediately after judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 28 Order IV of the Rules of Madras High Court, which runs as follows When an appeal against an appellate decree or order has been heard and disposed of by a single Judge, any application for a certificate that the case is a fit one for further appeal under clause 15 of the Letters Patent shall be made orally and immediately after the judgment has been delivered.

issues.text: Whether the voluntary sale under Ex. B7 is affected by the doctrine of lis pendens under section 52 TPA

anchor.surface_text: Expositions of the doctrine of lis pendens indicate that the need for it arises from the very nature of the jurisdiction of Courts and their control over the subject matter of litigation so that the parties litigating before them may not remove any part of the subject matter outside the power of courts to deal with it and thus make proceedings infructuous. The purpose of s. 52 of the Transfer of Property Act is not to defeat any just and equitable claim but only to subject them to the authority of the Court which is dealing with the property to which claims are put forward.

holdings.text: Rule 28 Order 4 of the Rules of the High Court of Madras Appellate Side is not ultra vires as it regulates the manner and time of application for Letters Patent appeal certificate under cl.15 without taking away the right.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court can regulate the time at which and the manner in which the application for certificate will be made. Rule 28 Order 4 does not take away any right conferred by cl. 15 of the Letters Patent. It only regulates the manner of the exercise of that right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court empowered under Letters Patent cl.37 to make rules regulating proceedings; rule prescribes mode, not destroys right; precedent Union of India v. Ram Kanwar followed.

holdings.text: Appeal is maintainable despite failure to apply orally and immediately for Letters Patent certificate as special leave granted under Art.136, case advanced without objection, and merits heard.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case although the appellant was not shown to have attempted any explanation of failure to apply for the certificate at the proper time, yet, the special leave petition having been granted and the case having passed without objection, beyond the stage of interim orders and printing of records, the Court heard arguments on merits also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.136 discretionary, no inflexible rule to refuse leave if LP remedy not exhausted; Penu Balakrishna distinguished as no general rule; facts of case warrant hearing on merits.

holdings.text: Voluntary sale under Ex. B7 is hit by doctrine of lis pendens under s.52 TPA as it does not purport to be on behalf of joint family, excludes plaintiff, and parties denied jointness.

anchor.surface_text: An examination of the sale deed Ex. B7 disclosed that it was not confined to the satisfaction of decretal amounts. Other items were also found in it. The sale deed did not purport to be

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale not in execution of decree but voluntary; sellers exclude coparcener plaintiff; denial of joint family status precludes binding whole family; exemption from lis pendens not for voluntary sales.

holdings.text: Revenue sale under Ex. B51 is affected by lis pendens except insofar as properties for improvement of which loans under Land Improvement Loans Act s.7 were taken; purchaser protected by allotment to seller's share.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding Ex. B51 the High Court... held that only that land sold was to be excluded from the purview of the principle of lis pendens for the improvement of which some loan was taken.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lis pendens applies to revenue sales like court auctions; LILA s.7(1)(a) recovery from borrower only, proviso s.7(1)(c) protects prior interests; statutory recovery limited to borrower's interest; direction to allot safeguards purchaser.

holdings.text: Principle of lis pendens applies to involuntary alienations including court auctions and revenue sales, though effect may vary based on pre-existing rights.

anchor.surface_text: If the principle of lis pendens applies to court auctions there is no reason why it should not apply to revenue sales. But the effect of the application of the principle may vary

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.52 TPA language covers court sales; precedents like Radhamadhub Holdar, Motilal; purpose is court control over subject-matter, not defeat just claims.

holdings.text: Sales Ex. B7 and B51 not binding on joint family as not made for legal necessity by karta; parties denied jointness and did not claim as family alienations.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court had found that the properties given in Schedule B were joint family properties of which the defendant respondent Munisami was the karta in possession. This finding was affirmed by the first Appellate Court and was not touched in the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts found joint properties, Munisami karta; but no pleading or proof of legal necessity; denial of jointness by sellers and purchaser precludes binding non-sellers.

holdings.text: Direction to allot properties covered by Ex. B7 and B51 to Munisami's share in partition is correct to protect purchaser's just claim without violating lis pendens.

anchor.surface_text: the Commissioner who was to divide the properties by metes and bounds, was directed to allot to Munisamis share, so far as possible, properties which were covered by Exhibit B.7, and B.51.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Safeguards purchaser if properties fall to seller's share; aligns with lis pendens purpose to subject claims to court decree without defeating equities.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal lacking merit and dismissed with costs. High Court judgment upheld: voluntary sale hit by lis pendens; revenue sale partially excluded only for properties improved via Land Improvement Loans Act loans.
directions: Trial court to receive evidence identifying properties improved with loans under Land Improvement Loans Act and exclude lis pendens application to those.
Allot sold properties to first defendant's share insofar as possible to protect purchaser's rights against that share.
